user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl:
```c
static void OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(fd_set *OS_set, OS_FdSet *OSAL_set)
{
    size_t       offset;
    size_t       bit;
    osal_index_t id;
    uint8        objids;
    int          osfd;

    for (offset = 0; offset < sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids); ++offset)
    {
        objids = OSAL_set->object_ids[offset];
        bit    = 0;
        while (objids != 0)
        {
            id = OSAL_INDEX_C((offset * 8) + bit);
            if ((objids & 0x01) != 0 && id < OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES)
            {
                osfd = OS_impl_filehandle_table[id].fd;
                if (osfd < 0 || !FD_ISSET(osfd, OS_set))
                {
                    OSAL_set->object_ids[offset] &= ~(1 << bit);
                }
            }
            ++bit;
            objids >>= 1;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OSAL_set->object_ids[offset] &= ~(1 << bit);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The expression modifies OSAL_set->object_ids (using &=) so OSAL_set must point to a non-const object; Rule 8.13 requires pointers to point to const-qualified types only when they need not be modified. The fragment therefore correctly uses a non-const target. (Note: the other parameter OS_set is only read and could be declared as pointer-to-const, but that is outside the specific fragment.)
